subject: Art & Design
title: Social Proof: Designing for the Herd Instinct
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Social Proof: Designing for the Herd Instinct.

hook.text: '4,000 people are viewing this hotel right now.' Suddenly it feels popular, scarce, and worth booking.

buildup.text: Social proof is the psychological tendency to follow what others are doing, especially in uncertain situations.

discovery.text: Reviews, testimonials, user counts, 'bestseller' badges, and influencer endorsements are all social proof triggers.

twist.text: Fake reviews erode trust. Amazon's verified purchase badge was created specifically to counter fake social proof.

climax.text: Airbnb shows host response rates. GitHub shows star counts. LinkedIn shows connection counts. Numbers build credibility.

punchline.text: People don't trust products. They trust other people who trust products.

quiz.question: Why is social proof effective in design?
options: People follow others' behavior, especially when uncertain about decisions
Users ignore what other people think
Social proof only works in social media apps
